cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: The proper footwear for riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Has short heels.
questions.answerC: Has tall heels.
questions.answerD: Is always sneakers.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should wear sturdy footwear that is high enough to cover and support your ankles. Short-heeled footwear is best because taller heels may catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so that they can't be caught on anything.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Allow you to set up for turns.
questions.answerB: Allow an escape route.
questions.answerC: Allow you to avoid wind blasts from other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Allow you to be in another vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Have only a rear brake.
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: Which of the following types of footwear is best for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerB: Tennis shoes
questions.answerC: Shoes with loose laces
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: Sturdy boots or shoes that are high enough to support the ankles can provide the best protection for motorcyclists. Laced up boots are best, but high-top boots or heavy shoes are fine. If a motorcyclist wears shoes that have long laces, they should be sure to securely tuck the laces away before riding.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerB: Full-fingered gloves
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerC: Push their bike over.
questions.answerD: Encourage friends to talk them out of riding.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding. It can be helpful to recruit a group of friends to intervene and apply peer pressure to the person.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerB: On short trips.
questions.answerC: On long rides.
questions.answerD: Several hours into the ride.
questions.explanation: Most crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: When changing lanes, riders should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on their mirrors to identify other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Turn their head to look for traffic behind them.
questions.answerC: Not worry about other traffic.
questions.answerD: Slam on the brakes to allow any vehicles in their blind spot to pass.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle has blind spots just like any other vehicle. A rider must always turn their head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: Engine braking:
questions.answerB: Is slowing down by turning the engine off.
questions.answerC: Is slowing down by downshifting.
questions.answerD: Is not encouraged because of the damage it does to the engine.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the lead rider.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should not rely on their mirrors to see what’s going on around them because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle mirrors are smaller than the mirrors on other vehicles, so you can't see as much.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles, like cars, have blind spots.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are never accurate.
questions.answerD: Mirrors take your eyes off the road in front of you and they should not be used.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles, like any other vehicle, have blind spots. Therefore, you cannot rely only on your mirrors to know what is happening behind you. Frequent head checks should be part of your normal routine.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerB: Should not balloon when riding.
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: A skidding rear tire:
questions.answerB: Eliminates your ability to change direction.
questions.answerC: Will usually correct itself.
questions.answerD: Is only a concern if the front tire is also skidding.
questions.explanation: A skidding rear tire is a dangerous condition that can result in a violent crash and serious injury or death. Too much rear brake pressure can cause the rear wheel to lock. As soon as the rear wheel locks, your ability to change direction is lost. To regain control, the brake must be released.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not wear a jacket if it's warm out.
questions.answerB: Always wear a jacket, even if it’s warm out.
questions.answerC: Wear shorts in warm weather.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about long shoelaces.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket made of appropriate material when riding. This is true even in warm weather because wearing a jacket is important to help prevent dehydration. You should also always wear long pants, and tuck in the laces of your footwear to prevent them from catching on the motorcycle.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerB: Slow down before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: Your street-legal motorcycle must have all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: One mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn signals.
questions.answerD: A horn.
questions.explanation: At minimum, a street-legal motorcycle must have a headlight, taillight, and brake light; front and rear brakes; turn signals; a horn; and two mirrors.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: When packing a load on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The heavier items should go toward the front.
questions.answerB: The heavier items should go toward the rear.
questions.answerC: Mounting loads behind the rear axle is recommended.
questions.answerD: Lighter items should be stored in front of you.
questions.explanation: Loads should be positioned forward with heavier items toward the front of the load. Loads should be over or in front of the rear axle. Lighter items should be packed behind you.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerB: Take more than an hour.
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Don’t worry about checking the tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Expect it to handle the same as your own bike.
questions.answerC: The lender will make sure the brakes work so you don't have to.
questions.answerD: Give yourself an extra cushion of space when riding to allow more time to react.
questions.explanation: If you borrow a motorcycle, make all of the same pre-ride safety checks that you would make on your own motorcycle. You should ride cautiously when using an unfamiliar motorcycle and allow yourself extra space when stopping.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerB: Seat.
questions.answerC: Suspension.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerB: Adjust the handlebars.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerB: Once reaching the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: In any crash, you have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Wear face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Have a windshield.
questions.explanation: You can reduce your risk of injury when riding a motorcycle by wearing an approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerB: After several hours of riding.
questions.answerC: On short trips.
questions.answerD: On long trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles in length at speeds slower than 30 mph.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerB: Improper loading
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerB: Do both at the same time.
questions.answerC: Always apply the brakes first, then swerve.
questions.answerD: Try instead to use only the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should perform both actions separately. Brake then swerve, or swerve then brake. Do not do both at the same time.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: If your motorcycle is being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Ride alongside the dog.
questions.answerC: Stop until the dog loses interest.
questions.answerD: Approach the dog slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind. If you encounter a larger animal, brake and prepare to stop.

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders:
questions.answerA: Should wear hearing protection at all times to prevent hearing damage.
questions.answerB: Should only wear hearing protection during long rides.
questions.answerC: Should not wear hearing protection because it will muffle other noises, such as horns and sirens.
questions.answerD: Do not need to use hearing protection if they are using a helmet.
questions.explanation: Longterm exposure to wind and engine noise can cause permanent hearing damage, even if the rider is wearing a full-face helmet. Wearing ear plugs or other hearing protection can guard against damage while still allowing the wearer to hear important sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Involve riders who have operated their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.answerB: Are caused by faulty ignition systems.
questions.answerC: Occur because of distractions caused by passengers.
questions.answerD: Happen at night.
questions.explanation: Always be very careful when riding a motorcycle that is new to you. In most motorcycle crashes, the operator had less than six months of experience on the bike that they were riding.

questions.question: When passing parked cars, which part of the lane should you usually use?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: Either the left or right portion of the lane
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is often safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. Riding in the left portion will keep you farthest from any opening car doors, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerB: Near the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located next to the right handgrip. It is important to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before starting out.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerB: Alert the local police.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In any part of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the part of the lane closest to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: In the part of the lane that places your image in the car's rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: As close to the car as possible.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerB: Loosening the chain
questions.answerC: Using the throttle more
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerB: Meets U.S. DOT standards.
questions.answerC: Has survived a previous crash.
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerB: Is well-worn and broken in.
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes gradually.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have ridden their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.explanation: Always take extra care when riding a new or unfamiliar motorcycle. Most crashes involve riders who have had less than six months of experience with the motorcycle that they are using.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: The left position in the lane
questions.answerB: The center position in the lane
questions.answerC: The right position in the lane
questions.answerD: There is no single lane position that is best for all situations.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for your current riding conditions, allowing you to maintain an adequate space cushion and be visible to others.

questions.question: More than half of all motorcycle crashes:
questions.answerB: Are caused by bald tires.
questions.answerC: Occur at speeds above 55 mph.
questions.answerD: Involve inexperienced riders.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders who have been using their motorcycle for less than six months. Most crashes take place in broad daylight when the riders are traveling at low speeds.

questions.question: A motorcycle needs:
questions.answerA: Less frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerB: More frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerC: To have pre-ride checks performed only by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: To be serviced only at a dealer.
questions.explanation: Because a small technical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car, motorcycles need to be checked more frequently. Complete a thorough check before every ride.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: To help other drivers see you, you should wear:
questions.answerB: Brightly-colored clothes.
questions.answerC: Lights.
questions.answerD: A black jacket.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing will help you to be seen by other road users. Wear clothes that increase your visibility both during the day and at night.

questions.question: Of the following, which should you not do to improve your safety when riding at night?
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlight whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: To ride safely at night, you should reduce your speed, use your high beam headlight when you are not riding near other vehicles, and increase your following distance. Take advantage of vehicles ahead of you to provide clues about the upcoming road. Their headlights may help to illuminate the road ahead and their taillights will bounce up and down if the vehicle is being driven over bumps on the road.

questions.question: When riding under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least four seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Sunglasses
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may exceed the speed limit until the pass is complete.
questions.answerB: You may disregard "No passing zone" markings if the pass was started in a passing zone.
questions.answerC: You may pass on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: You must complete the pass within the posted speed limits and within a legal passing zone.
questions.explanation: Passes must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes immediately.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and gradually close the throttle.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: Lane sharing is:
questions.answerB: Prohibited.
questions.answerC: Allowed in heavy traffic to maximize lane space.
questions.answerD: Allowed if there is adequate lane space for both vehicles.
questions.explanation: Like other vehicles, motorcycles need a full lane width to operate safely. For this reason, lane sharing is generally prohibited.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: At a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: When a group of riders is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should:
questions.answerB: Pass in a staggered formation with several riders passing at the same time.
questions.answerC: Pass one at a time.
questions.answerD: Avoid passing.
questions.explanation: When a group of motorcyclists is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should pass the vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete their pass before the next rider's pass begins.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Protection in a collision.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: What should a motorcyclist do to prevent possible injury when riding on a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: Reduce their speed.
questions.answerC: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When riding on a slippery surface, it is safest to decrease your speed. Making sudden moves on a slippery surface could cause your motorcycle to skid. Do not travel on the shoulder to escape a slippery road.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a piece of protective clothing for a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: When riding, it is safest for a motorcyclist to wear a helmet, eye protection, a jacket, long pants, sturdy boots, and gloves.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, it is important that all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerB: The helmet looks nice.
questions.answerC: The helmet fits snugly.
questions.answerD: The helmet does not have any defects.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you have a helmet that will provide the best possible protection, you should choose one that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards. It should fit snugly all the way around and have no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerB: About one-half
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: Most crashes occur in broad daylight. To be more visible, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-clothing.
questions.answerC: Ride without your headlight.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: Because most crashes happen in broad daylight, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: A DOT-approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Restricts the wearer's vision to the sides.
questions.answerB: Can greatly reduce the severity of a head injury.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Makes it more difficult for the wearer to control their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet while riding greatly improves your chances of avoiding serious injury to your head or neck in the case of a crash. A DOT-approved helmet will not restrict your vision to the sides.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A driveway
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: Unlike most food and drinks, alcohol does not need to be digested. This means that:
questions.answerA: Within minutes of being consumed, the alcohol reaches the brain and begins to affect the drinker.
questions.answerB: The alcohol never gets removed from the body.
questions.answerC: It takes a long time to feel the effects of alcohol.
questions.answerD: Once it is in your system, your body gets rid of the alcohol quickly.
questions.explanation: Because it does not have to be digested, alcohol enters a person's bloodstream quickly and reaches the brain within minutes. It gets eliminated from the body at a relatively slow rate: about one drink per hour.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger in a sidecar, you should:
questions.answerB: Begin slowing later than usual.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes more firmly than usual to stop quickly.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes more softly than usual to keep from overworking them.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger in a sidecar will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to require extra space to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: The gear shift lever is located:
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest.
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest.
questions.answerC: Behind the left footrest.
questions.answerD: Behind the right footrest.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the left foot. To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift. To downshift, press the shift lever down.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: An experienced rider:
questions.answerA: Changes positions within their lane as conditions change.
questions.answerB: Stays in one portion of a lane at all times.
questions.answerC: Weaves within the lane to be more visible.
questions.answerD: Travels only on the oily portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Unlike drivers of larger vehicles, a motorcyclist has three lane position options in their travel lane. The rider should select whichever position is safest based on road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake on slippery surfaces, such as wet pavement.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop, regardless of the condition of the road.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcyclist should tell the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the seat.
questions.answerC: Put their feet on the muffler.
questions.answerD: Mount the motorcycle after the motorcycle has been started.
questions.explanation: Even if your passenger is also a motorcyclist, you should give them complete safety instructions before leaving on a trip. Ask them to get on the motorcycle only after you have started the engine. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding you and firmly hold onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when the bike is stopped.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer in a weaving pattern.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: If you are riding and your motorcycle starts to handle differently, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and check the tires.
questions.answerC: Pull over to check the chain.
questions.answerD: Pull over to check the windshield.
questions.explanation: A sudden change in handling may indicate that a tire on your motorcycle has failed. If you feel a change in the way your motorcycle handles, pull over safely and check your tires.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerB: Safe, even if used improperly.
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use any brakes, but downshift.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed and avoid making sudden moves. Use both brakes if you must slow down or stop.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best riding formation is generally:
questions.answerB: A staggered formation.
questions.answerC: A single-file line.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally best when riding in a group. You should move into a single-file line when turning, riding in a curve, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: When using a motorcycle with which you are unfamiliar, you should:
questions.answerA: Test the seat to make sure it is comfortable.
questions.answerB: Assume the motorcycle is in good riding condition.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times before riding.
questions.answerD: Ride as you usually do, since most bikes are similar.
questions.explanation: Since all motorcycles are somewhat different, you should be very careful when using one that is new to you. Familiarize yourself with the motorcycle before setting off. Learn the gear pattern before riding by working the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerB: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to prevent a friend from driving while intoxicated?
questions.answerA: Arrange a safe ride home for them.
questions.answerB: Get them involved in activities to slow their drinking and keep them busy while they sober up.
questions.answerC: Make them wait 15 minutes after their last drink before driving.
questions.answerD: Get other friends involved in stopping your friend from driving.
questions.explanation: To prevent someone from drinking and driving, it is a good idea to arrange an alternative way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to keep them from leaving, and recruit friends to help apply peer pressure.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: If your motorcycle has convex mirrors and you are not familiar with this type of mirror, you should practice using the mirrors because:
questions.answerA: Most people aren’t used to using mirrors.
questions.answerB: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look farther away than they really are.
questions.answerC: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look closer than they really are.
questions.answerD: It can be difficult to remember to look at mirrors while riding.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have operated the involved motorcycle for less than six months.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders with less than six months of experience on the motorcycle being used.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerB: Signal and use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: Moving into another lane while taking a curve is often the result of:
questions.answerB: Lanes that are too narrow.
questions.answerC: Not knowing how to steer.
questions.answerD: Lanes that are too wide.
questions.explanation: Trying to enter a curve or turn at a speed that is too fast for conditions may cause you to cross into another lane of traffic or leave the road entirely.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: It is best to not ride directly alongside another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: You may be riding in its blind spot.
questions.answerB: It is distracting to have a vehicle next to you.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may want to use the lane.
questions.answerD: It would be difficult to see what is happening behind you.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to ride directly alongside a vehicle in another lane because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will have no way of knowing you are there. It can also be dangerous because the vehicle may block your path of escape if another hazard arises.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerB: The steering will feel loose.
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: When downshifting, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift through multiple gears at a time.
questions.answerB: Shift through one gear at a time.
questions.answerC: Always shift all the way down to neutral first.
questions.answerD: Accelerate.
questions.explanation: When shifting into a lower gear, shift down one gear at a time and ease out the clutch through the friction zone between each downshift.

questions.question: When traveling in a group, riders should:
questions.answerA: Spread out to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerB: Stay close together to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerC: Separate occasionally.
questions.answerD: Ride in pairs.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, riders should maintain close ranks while also allowing adequate space cushions around each rider. Staying close together makes the group easier to see and reduces the risk that riders will become separated. Riders should not pair up because doing so does not allow adequate room for them to maneuver.

questions.question: Just like cars, motorcycles have blind spots. When switching lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Look only at your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Rely on your peripheral vision.
questions.answerD: Slow down so any vehicle in your blind spot can pass you.
questions.explanation: Blind spots, by definition, are areas that you cannot see by just looking in your mirrors. Turn your head to the side and check over your shoulder for vehicles in your blind spot before you change lanes.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerB: The pavement is wet.
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: If you are using an unfamiliar motorcycle, what should you do before riding?
questions.answerA: Ride like you would on your bike, since all bikes are about the same.
questions.answerB: Check the controls and shift pattern.
questions.answerC: Take the owner’s word that everything is in working order.
questions.answerD: Assume you know where all the controls are located.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are slightly different, so you should check the controls and make sure you know the gear pattern before riding an unfamiliar motorcycle. Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times prior to riding.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, a jacket should be worn:
questions.answerB: Only on cool days.
questions.answerC: Only on warm days.
questions.answerD: Only if the ride will be longer than half an hour.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket when riding, even in warm weather when you may not think you need a jacket. It can help protect you against the sun and dehydration in hot weather.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
