questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Be flexible about your lane position and adjust to changing conditions.
questions.answerB: Travel at a faster speed than usual to get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Always use your low beam headlight to see better.
questions.answerD: Decrease your following distance so you can be as close as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night. Be especially careful to employ safe riding strategies when riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Requires little traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: When you are stopped, you:
questions.answerB: Should remain in neutral.
questions.answerC: Should remain in fifth gear.
questions.answerD: Can remain in any gear.
questions.explanation: Shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Remain in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly if needed.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerB: Only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Both brakes.
questions.answerD: Either brake, but never both at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always simultaneously use both brakes to stop. The brakes are most effective when used at the same time.

questions.question: Goggles can:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes and your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protect your eyes, but not your face.
questions.answerD: Not protect your face or eyes.
questions.explanation: Goggles can protect your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face in a crash.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A strip of oil in the center of a lane
questions.answerC: Mud on pavement
questions.answerD: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; oily areas; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time could result in all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Hypothermia.
questions.answerC: Severe chills.
questions.answerD: Hot flashes.
questions.explanation: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time can cause severe chill, fatigue, and even hypothermia. Be sure to wear proper clothing to protect you from the elements.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should travel:
questions.answerA: More slowly than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerB: At the speed you would travel during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerC: Faster than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road so other vehicles can see you.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, travel at a slower speed than you would during the day under similar weather and traffic conditions. It can be difficult to see potential hazards in the dark, so slowing down can increase your chances of avoiding any hazards.

questions.question: A rectangular sign may be a:
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.answerD: Speed limit sign.
questions.explanation: Signs informing road users of road regulations, such as speed limits, are normally rectangular and colored white with black lettering or symbols. Riders must follow the rules posted on these regulatory signs.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the most protection when worn by motorcyclists?
questions.answerB: Denim
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Wool
questions.explanation: Leather jackets and pants provide the greatest level of protection when riding.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerB: Should hang loose.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: Convex mirrors make cars seem:
questions.answerB: Farther away.
questions.answerC: Faster.
questions.answerD: Narrower.
questions.explanation: Rounded, or convex, mirrors provide a wider view of the road than flat mirrors, but they also make objects seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to:
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycles have a manual transmission. Downshifting to a lower gear will slow you down.

questions.question: The proper body position on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows you to sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Allows you to sit as far back as possible and have to stretch when trying to reach the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Makes you lean over the bike, requiring your arms to hold you up.
questions.answerD: Allows for your knees to be kept far from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips. This will permit you to easily and comfortably reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerB: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the lead rider.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader. This ensures that they won't have to chase after the group, and it allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: How much of a motorcycle's total braking power can the front brake supply?
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: About 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 70 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It supplies at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: If you are hit by a wind blast caused by a passing vehicle, you will have the most room for error if you are riding:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you are in the middle portion of your lane, you will have the greatest room for error if your control is disrupted by a wind blast from a passing vehicle.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerB: On the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: Riding gloves should:
questions.answerA: Not be worn because they will make your hands too hot.
questions.answerB: Be worn to provide a better grip on the handgrips.
questions.answerC: Not be worn because they will make it more difficult to work the controls.
questions.answerD: Be worn only on cooler days.
questions.explanation: Gloves made of leather, or another durable material, should be worn when riding. They will provide you with an improved grip on the handgrips, as well as help protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: As an operator, you should prepare a passenger to ride by instructing them to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as possible.
questions.answerC: Maintain a large space between themselves and you.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler and chains.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: When traveling behind another vehicle under normal conditions, a minimum following distance of ______ is recommended.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, maintaining a following distance of at least two seconds is recommended. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can improve their visibility by:
questions.answerB: Turning off their headlight.
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle very closely.
questions.answerD: Wearing brightly-colored clothing.
questions.explanation: To maximize your chances of being seen by other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: Which formation is best for keeping the riders in a group close together?
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerB: On long trips.
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: As weight transfers to the front of your bike while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Gradually increase pressure to the front brake.
questions.answerB: Use more rear brake pressure.
questions.answerC: Not worry. The weight transfer will not have an effect on your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Try to lock the front tire.
questions.explanation: While you are braking, gradually increase the amount of pressure applied to the front brake lever as the weight of the bike is transferred forward to the front tire.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerC: Travel in a zigzag motion.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Are even more important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless another vehicle is right next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are less important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Because motorcyclists are more vulnerable than the drivers of cars and trucks, appropriate use of signals by motorcyclists is even more important than it is for other drivers.

questions.question: During your pre-ride inspection, you should check all of the following, except the:
questions.answerB: Headlight and taillight.
questions.answerC: Turn signals.
questions.answerD: Reflectors.
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: The proper clothing for riding a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Cover your arms completely, but leave your legs exposed.
questions.answerC: Cover your legs completely, but leave your arms exposed.
questions.answerD: Be whatever makes you most comfortable, regardless of safety.
questions.explanation: To be adequately protected while riding, you should wear a jacket and pants that completely cover your arms and legs.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: If you are using an unfamiliar motorcycle, what should you do before riding?
questions.answerA: Ride like you would on your bike, since all bikes are about the same.
questions.answerB: Check the controls and shift pattern.
questions.answerC: Take the owner’s word that everything is in working order.
questions.answerD: Assume you know where all the controls are located.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are slightly different, so you should check the controls and make sure you know the gear pattern before riding an unfamiliar motorcycle. Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times prior to riding.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycle operators and other drivers?
questions.answerB: On highways
questions.answerC: On rural roads
questions.answerD: In parking lots
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers. Riders should use extra caution when approaching and riding through intersections.

questions.question: Just like cars, motorcycles have blind spots. When switching lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Look only at your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Rely on your peripheral vision.
questions.answerD: Slow down so any vehicle in your blind spot can pass you.
questions.explanation: Blind spots, by definition, are areas that you cannot see by just looking in your mirrors. Turn your head to the side and check over your shoulder for vehicles in your blind spot before you change lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe step in preventing fatigue while riding?
questions.answerB: Taking artificial stimulants
questions.answerC: Limiting the distance ridden in one day
questions.answerD: Taking frequent breaks
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest and try not to ride more than six hours in one day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements. Avoid taking artificial stimulants, as the effects when they wear off can be very dangerous.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic?
questions.answerB: Highways
questions.answerC: Parking lots
questions.answerD: Residential areas
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between your motorcycle and other traffic is at intersections. Be extra alert when riding somewhere where another vehicle may cross in front of your path of travel.

questions.question: How is the accelerator controlled?
questions.answerB: With the left hand
questions.answerC: With the right foot
questions.answerD: With the left foot
questions.explanation: The accelerator of a motorcycle is located by the right handgrip and is controlled with the right hand.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Sunglasses
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: Once a motorcycle helmet has been involved in a crash, it should be:
questions.answerB: Replaced.
questions.answerC: Sold to another rider.
questions.answerD: Outfitted with a new chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Replace any helmet that has been worn during a crash.

questions.question: When it is obvious that you are going to turn, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.answerB: Should still use a turn signal.
questions.answerC: Only need to use a turn signal if there are nearby pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Only need to use a turn signal if you are at a stop light.
questions.explanation: You must use proper turn signals every time you turn or change lanes, even if you think your intentions are obvious. Signals are always important, even if no one else seems to be around to see them. There may be other vehicles nearby that you can't see or haven't yet noticed.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane usually contains an oily strip. This part of the lane is:
questions.answerB: Usually safe, unless the road is wet.
questions.answerC: Usually safe, unless it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Always safe, no matter the weather conditions.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: To reduce the amount of time you need to react to a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as school zones or construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes. This cuts down the amount of time you will need to react to a hazard.

questions.question: How can you regain control if your rear tire locks up?
questions.answerB: Continue using the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Swerve the bike in the direction with the fewest hazards.
questions.answerD: With the brake engaged, try to accelerate.
questions.explanation: To regain control of a locked rear wheel, the brake must be released. However, if you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: In hot weather, wearing a riding jacket:
questions.answerA: Can help protect against heat exhaustion and dehydration.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged because it can cause heat-related problems.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the jacket is a light color.
questions.answerD: Is not important.
questions.explanation: A riding jacket and long pants should still be worn when riding in hot weather. In addition to their other safety benefits, they can protect a rider from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

questions.question: A helmet will not provide the best possible protection:
questions.answerA: If it is certified by the DOT.
questions.answerB: If it fits snugly.
questions.answerC: If it is free of defects.
questions.answerD: If it has cracks.
questions.explanation: A helmet should meet U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards and fit snugly all the way around to provide maximum protection. It should be free of defects such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: When you ride, the best gear to wear is:
questions.answerA: Any gear that helps to protect you.
questions.answerB: The lowest-priced gear.
questions.answerC: Gear that looks good.
questions.answerD: Any gear that fits.
questions.explanation: You should wear gear that helps protect you while you ride. It is best to wear a DOT-approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerB: Adjust the handlebars.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.answerD: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as near intersections, shopping areas, school zones, and construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce the time you will need to react to potential hazards.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: If drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerA: Decide if you are still fit to ride based on how you feel after you finish drinking.
questions.answerB: Set a limit beforehand so you can still safely ride.
questions.answerC: Not ride.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about your riding abilities if you feel fine.
questions.explanation: The surest way to avoid the risks of riding under the influence of alcohol is to not ride after you have been drinking. Any amount of alcohol can impair your abilities.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not using your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is usually:
questions.answerA: Safest to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: Dangerous to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not safe to cross tracks on a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Safest to cross the tracks by riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is best to simply cross the tracks while riding straight within your lane. Turning to cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle could be dangerous because you could end up crossing into another lane of traffic.

questions.question: If you find yourself riding alongside another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver.
questions.answerC: Stay alongside the vehicle until the next exit and then exit.
questions.answerD: Let the other driver worry about it.
questions.explanation: Riding directly next to another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if another hazard arises. If you find yourself riding directly alongside another vehicle, either speed up or drop back.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Weave among the three portions of the lane as the vehicle passes.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally a good idea to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases your risk of a collision. Being on the side farthest from the passing vehicle may prompt the other driver to merge back into your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: If it is warm outside, should you wear a leather jacket while riding?
questions.answerA: No, it will make you too hot.
questions.answerB: Yes, but take frequent breaks to remove the jacket and cool off.
questions.answerC: Yes, riding jackets are made to keep the rider cool, even in warm weather.
questions.answerD: No, jackets get in the way of steering.
questions.explanation: In warm weather, a riding jacket will help prevent dehydration in addition to serving the basic protective function that it provides at all times. Many jackets are designed to protect riders against overheating, even in warm weather.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When riding in a group, what does it mean when the lead rider raises their left arm and extends their index finger, as shown in the image?
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerD: The group will pull off at the next exit.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. A lead rider raising their left arm and extending their index finger means that the group of riders should move into a single-file formation.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: How can you increase your ability to be seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Make sure you always ride using your headlight.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to vehicles in front of you.
questions.explanation: To maximize your ability to be seen at an intersection, ride with your headlight on and select a lane position that provides oncoming traffic with the best view of your motorcycle. Maintain a space cushion that allows you enough space to take evasive action if a hazard arises. You should never assume that making eye contact with a driver will be enough to make them consciously register your presence.

questions.question: If a rider in a group wants to ride faster than the others, what should the group do?
questions.answerA: Let the rider go ahead and meet up at a designated spot later.
questions.answerB: Speed up to accommodate the one rider.
questions.answerC: Split up and have every rider travel as fast or as slow as they want.
questions.answerD: Let the rider that wants to go faster lead the group.
questions.explanation: If one member of a group wants to ride faster than the others, it is best to let them go ahead of the group and meet at a designated spot later.

questions.question: A group of riders should pass another vehicle:
questions.answerB: In a pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: One at a time.
questions.answerD: In a splintered formation.
questions.explanation: On a two-lane highway, a group of riders should pass another vehicle one at a time. The second rider should not begin to pass until the first rider has safely re-entered the original lane. Riders should continue in this pattern until they have all safely passed the vehicle.

questions.question: If you are riding and your motorcycle starts to handle differently, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and check the tires.
questions.answerC: Pull over to check the chain.
questions.answerD: Pull over to check the windshield.
questions.explanation: A sudden change in handling may indicate that a tire on your motorcycle has failed. If you feel a change in the way your motorcycle handles, pull over safely and check your tires.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerB: Riding under the speed limit
questions.answerC: Wearing a helmet
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerB: Slow down before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerB: Should not balloon when riding.
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: Studies show that most crash-involved riders:
questions.answerA: Under-brake the front tire and over-break the rear tire.
questions.answerB: Over-break the front tire and under-brake the rear tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Most riders involved in crashes under-brake the front tire and over-brake the rear.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerB: Is well-worn and broken in.
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Keep your intentions hidden from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerC: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerD: Be close to the road signs.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: During acceleration, a sidecar attached to a motorcycle will:
questions.answerA: Feel like it is lagging behind.
questions.answerB: Feel like it is accelerating faster than the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Vibrate uncontrollably.
questions.answerD: Make acceleration seem faster.
questions.explanation: A sidecar is essentially an unpowered mass attached to the side of your motorcycle. Due to its inertia, it will feel like it is lagging behind when you accelerate.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: Riders who do not wear helmets while riding are ________ to die in a crash than riders who do wear helmets.
questions.answerB: Twice as likely
questions.answerC: Three times as likely
questions.answerD: Just as likely
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto their seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes immediately.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and gradually close the throttle.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Travel on the shoulder so you are not next to other traffic.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when braking is necessary, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be especially alert to oily areas, shaded areas, dirt, gravel, and bridges, as these surfaces may provide less traction than others.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Involve riders who have operated their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.answerB: Are caused by faulty ignition systems.
questions.answerC: Occur because of distractions caused by passengers.
questions.answerD: Happen at night.
questions.explanation: Always be very careful when riding a motorcycle that is new to you. In most motorcycle crashes, the operator had less than six months of experience on the bike that they were riding.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: Which of the following will best protect your eyes from wind?
questions.answerB: Sunglasses
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Goggles
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields will help protect your eyes from wind. Most windshields, as well as eyeglasses or sunglasses, will not.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding down the center of a lane under wet conditions. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by the cars ahead of you. The left tire track will often be best, but this can vary depending on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Using a turn signal
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: Shifting into a lower gear causes an effect similar to:
questions.answerB: Accelerating.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Shifting your motorcycle into a lower gear causes an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: When riding under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least four seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Avoid other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When should your rearview mirror be adjusted?
questions.answerB: Before starting the motorcycle
questions.answerC: During the ride
questions.answerD: At a traffic signal
questions.explanation: You should clean and adjust both mirrors before starting your motorcycle. Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you.

questions.question: If you are riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in a lane position that makes you visible to the driver.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your placement.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding directly behind a car, it is usually safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. If you are riding in the center of the lane, you are most likely to be visible in the rearview mirror of the vehicle ahead. Most drivers check their rearview mirror more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: Impairment from alcohol:
questions.answerB: Begins at about half of the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Occurs at the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Occurs only if you have had multiple drinks.
questions.explanation: As little as one drink can have a significant effect on the abilities that you need for safe riding. You can be impaired even if you are well below the legal blood alcohol limit. No amount of alcohol is safe to consume before riding.

questions.question: If your friend has been drinking alcohol, it is a good idea to do any of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Arrange for a safe ride home for your friend.
questions.answerB: Occupy your friend with activities to distract them from drinking.
questions.answerC: Keep your friend from leaving until they are sober.
questions.answerD: Allow your friend to ride their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from riding their motorcycle while impaired. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerB: Rider more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: Start slowing later than usual.
questions.answerD: Try to squeeze into smaller gaps in traffic.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to accelerate more slowly than usual, turn more slowly than usual, and require extra space to come to a complete stop. Ride more slowly, start slowing sooner when approaching a stop, open up a larger space cushion, and wait for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerB: Service
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: A way to lower the risk of being involved in a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.answerB: Not look ahead while riding.
questions.answerC: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerD: Ride in the parts of a lane that make it difficult to be seen.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When braking where traction is reduced, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes more quickly than usual.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes more gently than usual.
questions.answerC: Not use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Not use the front brake.
questions.explanation: When slowing or stopping on a surface with reduced traction, you should use caution and apply the brakes more gently than usual.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerD: Use your high beam light, if possible.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. Use your high beam headlight, except when following or meeting another vehicle.

questions.question: When choosing a lane position, you should consider:
questions.answerA: Whether or not other drivers will see you.
questions.answerB: How many cars are on the road ahead.
questions.answerC: Which portion of the lane will result in a shorter trip.
questions.answerD: If you can pass more vehicles in a certain position than in another.
questions.explanation: While a properly chosen lane position can offer several advantages, you should be certain that your lane position will allow you to be seen by others and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerB: Slow down
questions.answerC: Speed up
questions.answerD: Exit
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. This hand signal means "follow me."

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: At a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothing.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: To carry a passenger, you may need to adjust all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Mirror positions.
questions.answerC: Headlight position.
questions.answerD: Brake light position.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle carrying a passenger will sit differently than usual due to the additional weight. You may need to adjust the tire pressure, suspension, shocks, headlight, and mirrors to compensate for the shift.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: A helmet should not:
questions.answerB: Fit snugly.
questions.answerC: Be without obvious defects.
questions.answerD: Have been previously worn in an accident.
